qas.question: What face buttons do SNES controllers have that NES controllers didn't?
How many shoulder buttons do SNES controllers have?
What color are the US SNES controllers' X and Y buttons?
What color are the US SNES controllers' A and B buttons?
What face buttons do NES controllers have that aren't on the SNES controllers?
What was also designed by Dreamcast?

plausible_answers.text: PlayStation, Dreamcast, Xbox, and Wii Classic Controller

qas.question: What consoles controller designs are inspired by the Japanese system logo?
What color are the shoulder buttons X and Y in Japan?
How many shoulder buttons are incorporated into the Japanese system logo?

context: The standard SNES controller adds two additional face buttons <b5_0>(<a0_0>X and Y<a0_0/>)<b5_0/> to the design of the NES iteration, arranging the four in a diamond shape, and introduces <a1_0>two<a1_0/> shoulder buttons. It also features an ergonomic design by <a2_0>Lance Barr<a2_0/>, later used for the <b6_0>NES-102 model controllers<b6_0/>, also designed by Barr. The Japanese and PAL region versions incorporate the colors of the <b9_0>four<b9_0/> action buttons into system's logo. The North American version's buttons are colored to match the redesigned console; the X and Y buttons are <a3_0><b8_0>lavender<b8_0/><a3_0/> with concave faces, and the A and B buttons are <a4_0>purple<a4_0/> with convex faces. Several later consoles derive elements of their controller design from the SNES, including the <b7_0>PlayStation, Dreamcast, Xbox, and Wii Classic Controller<b7_0/>.
